description: From Middle English hoop, hoope, from Old English hōp (“mound, raised land; in combination, circular object”), from Proto-Germanic *hōpą (“bend, bow, arch”) (compare Saterland Frisian Houp (“hoop”), Dutch hoep (“hoop”), Old Norse hóp (“bay, inlet”)), from Proto-Indo-European *kāb- (“to bend”) (compare Lithuanian kabė (“hook”), Old Church Slavonic кѫпъ (kǫpŭ, “hill, island”)). More at camp.

entries.meaning: A circular band of metal used to bind a barrel.
A ring; a circular band; anything resembling a hoop.
examples: the cheese hoop, or cylinder in which the curd is pressed in making cheese

entries.meaning: A circular band of metal, wood, or similar material used for forming part of a framework such as an awning or tent.

(now chiefly historical) A circle, or combination of circles, of thin whalebone, metal, or other elastic material, used for expanding the skirts of ladies' dresses; (hence, by extension) a hoop petticoat or hoop skirt.
A quart pot; so called because originally bound with hoops, like a barrel. Also, a portion of the contents measured by the distance between the hoops.
(UK, obsolete) An old measure of capacity, variously estimated at from one to four pecks.
(basketball) The rim part of a basketball net.
(US, in the plural, metonymically) The game of basketball.
(sports, usually in the plural) A horizontal stripe on the jersey.
examples: Porto are playing from right to left in blue and white stripes, blue shorts and blue socks. Celtic are in their usual green and white hoops, with white shorts and white socks.

entries.meaning: (Australia, metonymically, slang, by extension) A jockey.
examples: The stewards ordered Des Coleman, the senior hoop (jockey) present, to ride and he got the horse home in a photo-finish.

entries.meaning: (figurative, usually in the plural) An obstacle that must be overcome in order to proceed.

verbs.description: hoop (third-person singular simple present hoops, present participle hooping, simple past and past participle hooped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bind or fasten using a hoop.
examples: to hoop a barrel or puncheon

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clasp; to encircle; to surround.
A shout; a whoop, as in whooping cough.

verbs.description: hoop (third-person singular simple present hoops, present participle hooping, simple past and past participle hooped)

entries.meaning: (dated) To utter a loud cry, or a sound imitative of the word, by way of call or pursuit; to shout.
(dated) To whoop, as in whooping cough.
